conversation.content: Good afternoon. I'm calling about our food service licensing account. We received an invoice showing a significant fee increase that we weren't notified about.

Good afternoon, and thank you for contacting us. I'd be happy to review your licensing account and clarify any concerns about the recent billing. May I have your business name and account number to pull up your information?
This is Riverside Stadium Concessions. Our account number should be under my name, Patricia Chen.

Thank you, Ms. Chen. I'm locating your account now. I can see Riverside Stadium Concessions under account number FSL-48927-RC with your primary food service license and three supplementary vendor permits active as of October 1st.
That's correct. We've held the same licensing structure for three years, but this month's invoice shows a thirty-five percent increase.

I understand your concern about the unexpected increase. Let me review your billing history and the current fee schedule. I can see your previous quarterly rate was $2,847.00, and the new invoice shows $3,843.45 for the upcoming quarter.
Exactly. That's nearly a thousand dollars more per quarter, which significantly impacts our operating budget. We need to understand why this happened.

Absolutely. I'm pulling up the fee adjustment notices now. According to our records, a regulatory update went into effect September 15th affecting all venues with capacity over 5,000 that serve both prepared foods and alcoholic beverages under license type FSL-B2.
We never received any notification about this change. How were we supposed to prepare for such a substantial increase?

I sincerely apologize that you weren't properly notified. The system shows notifications were sent to the email address admin@riverside-venue.org on July 22nd and August 19th, but I'd like to verify if that's still your preferred contact method.
That email was decommissioned six months ago. We submitted an update form changing it to operations@riversidestadium.com in April.

I see the issue now. Your contact update form CUF-7412-RS from April 14th is in our system, but it appears the email field wasn't properly migrated to your primary account notifications. This is absolutely our error, and I apologize for the oversight.
I appreciate you finding that. What can we do about this invoice, given we had no opportunity to budget for these changes?

Of course. Given the notification error on our end, I can offer you several options. We can apply a one-time adjustment credit of $487.50 to offset the increase for this quarter, and I can also set up a payment plan to spread the remaining balance over 90 days interest-free.
That would help considerably. Can you also ensure our contact information is corrected immediately so this doesn't happen again?

Certainly. I'm updating your primary notification email to operations@riversidestadium.com right now, and I'm adding a secondary contact as well if you'd like to provide one. The update confirmation number is UCN-9823-PC and will be active within the hour.
Please add my direct email as secondary, pchen@riversidestadium.com. Also, could you send documentation about these new regulations?

I've added your direct email as the secondary contact. I'll send the complete regulatory documentation package to both email addresses today, including the fee schedule breakdown and compliance bulletin RCB-2024-09 that details all the changes affecting your license category.
Perfect. Thank you for resolving this so efficiently. When will I receive the adjusted invoice and payment plan details?

You'll receive the adjusted invoice within two hours showing the $487.50 credit applied, bringing your quarterly total to $3,355.95. The payment plan agreement will arrive separately by end of business today, and your first installment of $1,118.65 won't be due until November 15th.

scenario: concessions manager, confused about food service licensing fee increases nobody mentioned
